Cassette,cassette,658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff611,658b0e5bf1b468de2a7ff7a4,68bf170e39eee98e77c80f05,false,false,Mon Sep 08 2025 17:49:02 GMT+0000 (Coordinated Universal Time),Wed Sep 10 2025 11:56:03 GMT+0000 (Coordinated Universal Time),Wed Sep 10 2025 13:59:25 GMT+0000 (Coordinated Universal Time),2,https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/68c02758eecfab1e24e66355_Bus%20Station%20Platform%201.png,Cassette,2024,Product Design • Art Direction,"

Cassette is an audio-based movie streaming platform. The concept was simple but overlooked: movies already have narrator tracks created by studios for accessibility, but those tracks rarely make it onto mainstream streaming platforms. Cassette set out to change that by turning movies into a fully audio experience, not just for the visually impaired community, but for anyone who wants to listen to movies on the go.

",https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/68c0280385a9e8e973edb73b_title.png
column2:
https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/68c02ee2673bf98602a3c5cb_cass.create%20and%20home.png,"
Goals:
  • Create an audio-first movie streaming platform.
  • Make existing narrator tracks accessible to broader audiences.
  • Design a simple, intuitive interface for browsing films and episodic content.
  • Position the product as both an accessibility tool and a new form of entertainment.
Target Audience:
  • Visually impaired users who rely on narrator tracks.
  • Movie fans who want to enjoy films while traveling or multitasking.
",https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/68c0327e0cc7911c8abb3b24_cass.Sopranos.png
column3:
https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/68c1671a0e426839b90aad24_cass.HookGood.png,"

The idea came from a friend who had long been thinking about the intersection of entertainment and accessibility. He brought the vision, I took on the design. Together we explored how to present large libraries of content, how to distinguish episodic series from feature films, and how to package the product so it felt familiar but distinct from existing streaming services.

My role was everything on the design side: branding, logo, marketing, website, and full UI/UX. I leaned on familiar streaming patterns from Netflix and Spotify to keep navigation effortless while shaping unique interactions tailored for audio-only use. For example, we designed a clever playback detail screen that revealed your position in the movie if you pressed and flipped the currently playing tile. This solved a tricky licensing challenge while still aligning with user needs.

As for accessibility, it wasn’t just a benefit of Cassette, but it was baked into it's core. One of the standout features was an LLM-powered search system that allowed users to ask for movies verbally. Instead of typing, a user could press a button, ask “What action movies should I listen to tonight?” and hear a spoken list of recommendations. From there, they could simply select one and start playback. This made the platform not only easier for visually impaired users navigating with screen readers but also opened up a more natural, conversational way to explore the library for everyone.

We built the app into TestFlight and proved that it worked technically. While industry restrictions on licensing ultimately kept Cassette from moving forward commercially, the product itself showed what was possible in an overlooked market.

",https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/68c032c5af1be7b2a6c50129_cass.Ask.png
column7:
https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/68c034441acdac312b7d7ded_cass.dude.png,,"

For me, this was the first time designing at the scale of a streaming platform. It meant handling content-heavy layouts, playback navigation, and discovery flows across a massive library. Streaming platforms are some of the most familiar interfaces we use every day, so it was a fun challenge to meet user expectations while putting a fresh twist on the experience.

Cassette was never released to the public, but the project gave me invaluable experience in designing for large-scale media consumption, balancing accessibility with mainstream appeal, and working at the intersection of design, technology, and industry constraints.

"

column1:
LassoPay,lassopay,658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff611,658b0e5bf1b468de2a7ff7a4,658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff644,false,false,Sun May 15 2022 12:28:31 GMT+0000 (Coordinated Universal Time),Thu Sep 18 2025 22:05:44 GMT+0000 (Coordinated Universal Time),Thu Sep 18 2025 22:05:44 GMT+0000 (Coordinated Universal Time),4,https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/6598ac24312d087df1939eef_lp.thumbnail2.png,LassoPay (Startup),2022,Product Design • Art Direction,"

LassoPay is an innovative Shopify app designed to transform how small businesses conduct transactions on Instagram. This app streamlines the purchasing process by enabling users to complete transactions with a single comment on a LassoPay enabled Instagram post.

",https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/658f584004fe572609262d6a_lp.site.Main.png
column3:
https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/658f584d237aa7cdadcddebb_lp.onboardpart2.png,"
Goals
  • Streamline the online purchasing process for Instagram users.
  • Enable businesses to easily track sales and affiliate attributions.
  • Provide a seamless integration between Instagram, Shopify, and payment processing.
Target Audience
  • Small to medium-sized businesses using Shopify.
  • Instagram users seeking a simplified shopping experience.
  • Merchants interested in leveraging influencer marketing.
Challenges

In development, the main challenge we faced was integrating the numerous complex systems necessary for a successful transaction. This included linking Instagram to Shopify merchants' accounts, ensuring secure payment processing through Stripe, and delivering a confirmation message to the user’s mobile number. The backend complexities were significant, but essential due to some obstacles we faced with permissions and restrictions from Meta and Shopify.

Our approach to refinement was heavily reliant on beta testing and user feedback. We engaged a small group of users to test the app's functionality, collecting their insights and experiences. This feedback was crucial for iterative improvements, helping us refine the onboarding flows and address any operational issues.

",https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/6590dfc0322c326ec88007d0_lp.prototype.comp.gif
column7:
https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/658f586b22d0bb27fece746d_lp.influ.Screens.png,"

The idea behind LassoPay was to streamline the customer journey by eliminating the usual hurdles associated with online transactions—navigating through a lengthy checkout process with multiple forms. We essentially turned the checkout process on its head, and included it as a one-time experience during the customer’s onboarding.

The onboarding process involved attaching your credit card and shipping address to your Instagram account. Once the user was set up, they could complete purchases by commenting on any LassoPay enabled Instagram post. This innovative approach not only delivered on user convenience, but did so without sacrificing any efficiencies in tracking sales statistics for merchants.

LassoPay was positioned to turn the industry on its head. Every design choice was a response to our user's needs—making their Instagram shopping experience as effortless and magical as possible.

Businesses using LassoPay would need to have a Shopify merchant account, and use the LassoPay merchant app. From the app’s dashboard, they import their products and assign Lasso shortcodes to each individual product.

When the merchant posts a product image and inserts the product’s shortcode in the IG caption, users could purchase that product with a single comment. Within sixty seconds they would have a confirmation text sent to their phones. Responding to which could allow you to cancel the order. We had a working version built out and this functionality worked flawlessly. It was magical.

We also offered specific features for merchants which allowed them to track and credit sales to different affiliates. Instead of traditional affiliate links, merchants could provide influencers with Lasso shortcodes. These shortcodes allowed merchants to track purchases made with LassoPay and which influencers were generating those purchases.

This allowed for a seamless and effortless way for merchants to identify their strongest influencer affiliates, and provided both parties with their own respective breakdown of revenue, orders, and attributions.

",https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/65909f0b1c11f34ee05c898b_lp.site.2up.png
column8:
https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/658f58723fcec2164853f417_lp.emailtemplates.png,,"

While the product worked, the back-end was a mess of technical and permission-based integrations. There were so many dependency issues, that if one broke it would have been a nightmare to rectify for the customer. We simply weren’t able to get the product into a stable enough state to push a commercialized launch.

Due to this lack of stability with purchases, the project took a strategic pivot—we considered shifting our focus to a wish-list app concept, but this was the beginning of the end of LassoPay. While it was an exciting project to launch and our optimism carried us for a while, our three-man team had to bow out to the reality that there were too many external obstacles working against us in our efforts to provide a stable platform for customers.

Reflections‍
  • User Reception: The app was highly praised by beta users for its groundbreaking approach to simplifying the checkout experience.‍
  • Technical Achievements: Despite the backend complexities, the app functioned flawlessly (however, delicately) in enabling transactions through Instagram comments.‍‍
  • Business Insights: It provided invaluable experience in app development, team collaboration, and the tough decisions required when facing technical and market barriers.
"

column1:
Lede,lede,658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff611,658b0e5bf1b468de2a7ff7a4,658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff64a,false,true,Sun May 15 2022 12:28:17 GMT+0000 (Coordinated Universal Time),Thu Sep 18 2025 22:02:16 GMT+0000 (Coordinated Universal Time),,6,https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/6598aab12473ac6bf1a7ffe9_lede.thumb.png,Lede (Startup),2020,Product Design • Concept Creation,"

Lede is an innovative digital platform designed to revolutionize the traditional job application process. It addresses the fundamental pain points candidates experience while job hunting, particularly focusing on the limitations of the one-page, paper/PDF resume.

",https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/6598aab99b128e0da46fc834_lede.main.png,"
Goals:
  • To identify and address the challenges faced by job seekers in presenting their career history.
  • To transform the conventional resume format into a more engaging and informative digital experience.
  • To provide a platform that showcases a candidate's complete history, including non-traditional experiences and passion projects.
  • To enhance the recruiters' experience by introducing a landscape, workstation-friendly format.
Target Audience:
  • Job seekers looking for a modern and effective way to showcase their career journey.
  • Recruiters and hiring managers seeking a comprehensive view of a candidate's professional and personal development.

",https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/6598aab9222c05e459d76b08_lede.jobdetail.png
column2:
https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/6598aab968533b35ff2e5994_lede.project.png,"

The initial phase of the project focused on understanding the limitations of the traditional resume and how these could be transformed in a digital landscape. Recognizing that recruiters primarily use workstations and desktops, the design shifted to a landscape format, laying the foundation for the timeline feature.

The timeline became the core of Lede's user experience (UX). It effectively addressed several UX issues with traditional resumes, such as space constraints and content organization. This feature allowed for chronological or categorical arrangement of a candidate's history, with an innovative 'storyboard' section on the right half of the screen. This storyboard could display detailed information, including digital works like images, written content, code, and hyperlinks.

Lede introduces a dynamic and visual approach to presenting a candidate's career history through a timeline format, offering a more comprehensive and engaging portrayal of an individual's professional journey.

An essential aspect of the design process was the inclusion of non-traditional life experiences, such as career gaps, in the timeline. Recognizing that these gaps often lead to negative perceptions, Lede recontextualizes them, portraying them as valuable and enriching experiences. This approach aimed to provide a holistic view of a candidate's journey, promoting a more favorable perception among recruiters.

Contributions:

  • Conducted in-depth research on job seekers' challenges and recruiters' preferences.
  • Developed the concept of transforming traditional resumes into a dynamic timeline format.
  • Designed and implemented the storyboard feature to display detailed information and digital works.
  • Ensured the platform was optimized for viewing on workstations and desktops.
  • Integrated features to highlight non-traditional experiences and reframe job gaps positively.
",https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/6598aac6e94344098d4e115a_lede.mobile.png

column1:
","

While the Lede platform brought forward an innovative approach to career representation, it unfortunately never saw a market launch due to challenges in securing funding. Despite this, the conceptualization and development of Lede highlighted significant gaps in the traditional job application process and proposed meaningful solutions.

The design and features of Lede, especially the timeline and storyboard components, received positive feedback for their potential to transform the way career histories are presented and evaluated. The project underscored the importance of considering non-traditional career paths and life experiences in a more positive light, challenging the conventional recruitment framework.

"

PopFlash,popflash,658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff611,658b0e5bf1b468de2a7ff7a4,658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff648,false,false,Sun May 15 2022 12:28:56 GMT+0000 (Coordinated Universal Time),Tue Sep 09 2025 14:08:57 GMT+0000 (Coordinated Universal Time),Tue Sep 09 2025 14:08:57 GMT+0000 (Coordinated Universal Time),5,https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/659857df1e9499eaed0d4ee8_pop.thumb2.png,Abstract Replacement (Contract),2021,Product Design • Visual Identity,"

PopFlash is a custom match-server platform for Counter-Strike: Global Offensive (CS:GO), and aimed to transform the experience of players seeking higher, 128 tick servers. The objective was to revamp a basic, functional service into a visually appealing and user-friendly platform, tailored for a global audience.

",https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/6591c8ff1c5f6aba779faa17_pop.profile.png
column4:
https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/6591c8b786f93610c22f7a7d_pop.scrimCaptainpPicking.png,"
Goals
  • Refresh the scrim page and core platform pages
  • Introduce analytical features that deepen engagement
  • Simplify the process of creating and joining matches
Target Audience

Our target audience included CS:GO players worldwide, with a particular focus on the European community, who were seeking 128 tick servers. Additionally, we catered to players who valued straightforward and intuitive custom match setup for groups and teams.

Our design approach was driven by the need to create an intuitive, engaging experience that resonated with our diverse, global audience.
UX
column5:
Approaches and Challenges
  • User journey optimization
  • Designing for clarity
  • Language and iconographic simplicity
  • Collaborative design and development
",https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/6591c8b71c5f6aba779f6fc6_pop.matchconnect.png
column6:
https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/6591c8b77d070f9c630bc434_pop.matchfinal.png,"

Redesigning PopFlash's UX demanded a deep understanding of player behavior and preferences. To cater to a global audience, we prioritized clear language and universally recognizable icons and abbreviations in the gaming community. Collaborative discussions with the owner and lead developer, were instrumental in balancing aesthetics with functionality.

Our approach focused on creating a seamless transition from login to gameplay, ensuring a intuitive navigation experience that enabled players to get into their match as easily and quickly as possible.

To host a match on PopFlash, only one of the ten players need to have a subscription. Player’s with a PopFlash subscription can then host scrims/matches from their community dashboard. As only one player needs to host the scrim, the other nine players to have an incredibly quick onboarding experience. Players click a link that was shared to them, login via Steam (the platform that hosts CS:GO), and they’re in—no additional data needed. No account sign up or email verification—it’s all through a shared platform every player already has a login for.

When players that have previously logged into PopFlash click on a match link, they drop right into the scrim lobby. This allows for pick-up games to be organized in seconds. When a scrim/match is launched, the scrim page automatically progresses to the match page.

On the match page, all players are provided with the necessary server information as well as a full display of live statistics from the match. After the match is finished, these scorecard stats remain active in a list of recent matches found on the hosting community’s dashboard.

Throughout this project, our unwavering commitment to delivering a super smooth experience for the players drove nearly every decision that was made.

This project went beyond visual enhancements and created a space where players felt valued and catered to.

Our iterative design process was backed by extensive beta testing and feedback sessions. We actively engaged with the PopFlash community on it’s Discord channel to gather players’ invaluable insights and feedback regarding usability and functionality. The working design and development sessions that followed were the driving force behind any design refinements.

",https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/65909c8c2aff0819be75caeb_pop.web.ALL.png
column8:
https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/65907f1f322c326ec84a4655_pop.comp.all.png,,"
Definitive successes
  • Elevated user experience
  • Sustained user engagement
  • Global accessibility

The platform's design, with its focus on clear language and universally recognizable icons, ensured accessibility to a diverse, global audience, allowing players from various regions to intuitively navigate and enjoy the CS:GO experience. As PopFlash underwent this visual transformation, it emerged as a more appealing and competitive choice in the market.

Players were happy. Scrims were hosted. Fun was had. After more than 18 months worth of work, we couldn't have asked for a better outcome.

"

column1:
Sloper - Climb Tracker,sloper,658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff611,658b0e5bf1b468de2a7ff7a4,68bf7da5184f7132f3a9da8c,false,false,Tue Sep 09 2025 01:06:45 GMT+0000 (Coordinated Universal Time),Tue Sep 09 2025 14:09:09 GMT+0000 (Coordinated Universal Time),Tue Sep 09 2025 14:09:09 GMT+0000 (Coordinated Universal Time),1,https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/68c00772e3a3fbb451348174_973shots_so%20(1).png,Sloper (Solo Founder),2025,Product Design • Development,"

Sloper is a climbing tracker designed for indoor and outdoor climbers, built to deliver the polished, intuitive experience missing from existing climbing apps. It allows users to log climbs, track projects, view progress with analytics, and compete with friends through leaderboards. With both free and premium features, Sloper gives climbers the same kind of seamless digital training companion that runners and cyclists have enjoyed for years.

",https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/68c016f14a4f8eda4f08d632_slop.home%20and%20session.png
column2:
https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/68c016f9dc6f49dccb5e2575_slop.add1%20and%202.png,"
Goals:
  • Solve a personal pain point with a climbing tracker that feels modern.
  • Make adding a climb the fastest and smoothest action in the app.
  • Support both beginners and advanced climbers with features that scale.
  • Launch a complete, revenue-generating product on the App Store.
Target Audience:
  • Climbers of any level who want to track their progress.
  • Beginners logging their first sessions.
  • Experienced climbers managing long-term projects and training data.
",https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/68c01709bc5c9011b3447d14_slop.projectsAll.png
column3:
https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/68c0170976216b3d45a6f3a8_slop.analytics1%20and%202.png,"

Sloper began as one of my first product concepts in 2020. At the time I didn't have the skills or resources to build it out, so it remained in my portfolio as just an another showcase piece. Years later, with more experience and the emergence of all these app building tools, I decided to take another shot. I redesigned it from scratch, focusing on the core experience of logging a climb, then started building.

I used v0.dev to get the foundation in place, then switched to a more manual approach with other LLMs as the project grew. I set up auth, wired up a Supabase backend, and integrated subscriptions through RevenueCat and App Store Connect. I built out an MVP in about a month, launched it through TestFlight, and kept iterating based on feedback from friends and early users. The product was originally released as a fully paywalled app, but the pushback was immediate. At the same time, I didn't want to prevent users from experiencing what I considered the most magical part of the app—the UX. So I took it to heart and reworked the offerings into two feature sets:
column4:
basic (free) and premium.

The hardest challenge wasn't anything design related, but the data structure behind it. I had to figure out how sessions, climbs, and projects would relate without conflicts, which is something I would normally collaborate on with engineers. Solving it on my own gave me a much deeper understanding of how data, code, and UX connect.

",https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/68c017176f139427667365e0_slop.HR%20and%20leaderboard.png

column1:
","

Sloper is now live on the App Store with a modest but active user base of around 170 climbers, consistent weekly activity, and five-star reviews. A growing number of users have subscribed to premium features, validating both the product and its business model.

As a solo designer / builder of Sloper, the learning experiences have been numerous and invaluable. I know now the complexities of a working codebase, inside and out. I better understand the relationship between front-end and back-end, and some of the parameters that I can be more mindful of when making certain design decisions. But more than anything, being the first time I have owned a product from conception to launch, this experience has made me sharper, more confident, and more effective in every part of the product development process.

"

Ukuu,ukuu,658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff611,658b0e5bf1b468de2a7ff7a4,658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff64b,false,false,Sun May 15 2022 12:28:45 GMT+0000 (Coordinated Universal Time),Thu Sep 18 2025 22:05:42 GMT+0000 (Coordinated Universal Time),Thu Sep 18 2025 22:05:42 GMT+0000 (Coordinated Universal Time),3,https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/659855683525d77521c695c3_thumbfinal.png,Ukuu (Startup),2022,Product Design,"

Ukuu is a dynamic peer-to-peer lending platform designed to leverage the gig economy and revitalize community connections through shared resources. It offers a dual-role system for users to list items or rent them, facilitated by an integrated messaging system and secure in-person exchanges.

",https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/6598528e25addaa5e034d4f1_Mainlisting.png
column2:
https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/659845f6b005318c21d7f978_Ukuu-Main-Experience-flow-fast(1).gif,"
Goals:
  • Capitalize on the gig economy by providing new income streams.
  • Foster community relationships through shared resources.
  • Create an intuitive and visually appealing platform.
Target Audience:
  • Individuals seeking additional revenue streams.
  • Users looking to monetize household items they are not frequently using.
  • Users trying to avoid expensive item purchases for one-time projects.
",https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/6598529aaf9329e44577d486_exchangeTextsMock.png
column4:
https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/65985456631361730504dda3_Listing%20Mock.png,"

Ukuu began with recognizing the disjointed experiences of individuals seeking used or temporarily needed items, such as power tools for one-off projects. Noticing that these essential tools were prohibitively expensive to purchase for short-term use, the idea for Ukuu was born.

The team saw an opportunity to streamline the process of renting items like these within local communities, making it more convenient and cost-effective than traditional methods like purchasing from stores or online marketplaces.

The initial phase of Ukuu’s development involved moving from this conceptual understanding to a tangible product. A rough mockup of the app was created, laying the foundational blueprint of what Ukuu was set to become. This version, although functional, was somewhat basic in its design and user experience. It served as a functional beta version that was essential for gathering initial user feedback and understanding the practical dynamics of peer-to-peer lending.

User feedback revealed the necessity for a trustworthy platform—one that looked more polished and in turn, secure. Moreover, practical issues such as insurance, liability, and the process for dealing with damaged items came to the forefront. These insights were instrumental in guiding the next steps of development.

",https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/659852b51de44bf2adf6d176_settingsMock.png
column5:
https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/658b0e5af1b468de2a7ff610/65980b47d8a9b66a4c3c00d0_ukuu.logo.png,,"

As the lead designer for Ukuu, I was responsible for elevating the initial app design from basic concepts to a polished, professional interface. I joined the project when it was still in the early stages, defined by functional but unsophisticated mockups.

My primary focus was on creating detailed, pixel-perfect mobile designs and prototypes that would serve as a blueprint for the development team. Beyond design, I played a key role in product iteration, actively participating in ideation sessions to refine UX flows and address specific challenges.

"
